atom:entry.atom:title: BlogEngine.NET Switch to BlogSvc
atom:entry.atom:content:
I’ve switched my blog from BlogEngine.NET to my very own BlogSvc.  I lose a few features (temporarily) but I gain huge amounts of confidence.  One of the top reasons for ditching BlogEngine.NET was how poorly the security is implemented.  In a previous post I detailed how a malicious user could delete comments from anyone’s blog running BlogEngine.NET 1.4.  BlogSvc was designed from the ground up to be secure and support multiple roles.

The process of switching was very straight forward.  I hacked up some code that would read a BlogML file and generate a new service document with a workspace and collection.  The service was then used to turn the blog posts (and comments) into atom entries.  Once this was done I simply uploaded all the files to my hosting provider.

I did hit one snag.  My hosting provider Aspnix has installed UrlScan on the IIS7 server.  This has the unfortunate side effect of blocking any PUT and DELETE commands.  So, until they update the UrlScan configuration, I won’t be able to use LiveWriter to update or delete posts.
